image.altText: US gun violence

items.synopsis: Serious family and domestic violence offenders will not be able to own firearms or gun licences under the latest element of sweeping gun reform by the WA government.

title.children: Firearms and gun licences to be stripped from DV offenders in response to spate of WA deaths

image.altText: A young woman follows through after kicking a football during an Aussie rules match, with other players nearby.

items.synopsis: Amateur female players call out derogatory and sexist online commentary after a low-scoring Perth Football League A-grade grand final, saying "older men" are to blame for the "disgusting" behaviour.

title.children: Losing their footy grand final was tough enough for these women. Then came the 'feral' sexist comments

image.altText: An aerial image shows a volcanic island emitting white smoke surrounded by clear blue sea on a clear day.

items.synopsis: Two tourism companies on trial over the deadly Whakaari White Island volcano eruption have had charges dismissed.

title.children: More White Island tourism companies have charges dismissed, just one defendant remains

image.altText: Karen Andrews holds her hands up while sitting under a patio in her Queensland home

items.synopsis: Former Coalition cabinet minister Karen Andrews has revealed she endured harassment inside the House of Representatives, with a male colleague breathing heavily on the back of her neck.

title.children: 'That was a great question, thrusting and probing': The harassment Karen Andrews endured inside parliament

image.altText: A man sitting, looking at the camera

items.synopsis: Mustafa Chiahad's son was buried beneath the rubble of his parents' home in Talat N'Yaaqoub. The town, near the epicentre of Morocco's earthquake, has turned in to ground zero for destruction.

title.children: 'I don't have the words to describe it': Devastated families count cost of Morocco's quake

image.altText: A group of rescuers in a cave lift a man on a stretcher using ropes

items.synopsis: Rescuers have pulled an American researcher out of a Turkish cave more than a week after he became seriously ill 1,000 metres below its entrance, said the Speleological Federation of Türkiye.

title.children: 'I kept throwing up blood': Researcher stuck in cave thought he was not going to live

image.altText: A shot from a boat looking down at a large coral boulder nearly 7 metres across and three people in wetsuits diving it

items.synopsis: Large bommies made of a stony coral known as porites underpin the World Heritage reef system. It's hoped they can help scientists predict how a warming world will affect the reef's health.

title.children: These 'old-growth trees' of the Ningaloo Reef are resistant to bleaching events — and scientists want to know why

image.altText: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un waves from a private train.

items.synopsis: Reports that Kim Jong Un is en route to Russia have drawn attention to the traditional method of travel for North Korean leaders — luxury, armoured trains that have long been a part of the dynasty's lore.

title.children: Kim Jong Un is on his way to Russia by rail. Here's a look at his luxury armoured train

image.altText: Child's arm dangles while in a car seat.

items.synopsis: The tragedy of children being forgotten in cars is becoming more common in Australia. A memory expert explains how it can happen to anyone.

title.children: Why memory failure can explain how children can be left forgotten in a car

image.altText: A pregnant woman in a white dress with a horse on a beach.

items.synopsis: Emma Goyne believes she picked up the parasitic infection while cleaning her horse stable, which a neighbouring cat had been using as a litter box. Now she's pushing for tougher cat laws.

title.children: Emma contracted toxoplasmosis while pregnant. Now she's calling for tougher roaming cat laws

image.altText: Cars and rubble sit in a street in Derna, Libya.

items.synopsis: Deadly storm winds and heavy floods have hit Libya over the past two days, with estimates of the number of people killed ranging from hundreds to thousands.

title.children: Thousands feared dead as storm floods Libya

image.altText: A man of Asian appearance wears glasses and stands speaking at a podium in a room, in front of a chalkboard and computer screens

items.synopsis: Banned from Australia over an alleged foreign interference plot in New South Wales, Chen Hong maintains he has done nothing wrong and continues to criticise the diplomatic stance taken by the former Coalition government.

title.children: Chinese scholar barred from Australia takes part in high-level dialogue between nations in Beijing

image.altText: Soldiers attempt to tow a vehicle stuck in mud

items.synopsis: Harsh winter conditions will bring new challenges in the war in Ukraine. The fighting will not stop, but it will change its tempo — and both sides will face different tests, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Could the Marshall Mud be Putin's undoing?

image.altText: An illustration of a pink egg in a blue nest with flying money notes with dollar signs on them

items.synopsis: As  the influence of superannuation funds – economically and politically — continues to grow, transparency over how member money gets used becomes crucial, writes Nassim Khadem.

title.children: With super assets set to top $9 trillion in 2041, should funds be more accountable about how they spend members' money?

image.altText: A woman with a ponytail and dark long sleeve top standing in front of a tree

items.synopsis: An expert says there's been a spike in pneumonia infections in people with healthy immune systems. Circus performer Caitlyn Larsson, who had the infection for three months this year, is one of them.

title.children: Why are even healthy people getting sick with pneumonia this year?

image.altText: A woman in a red hat leaning on a rusty bar of a gate.

items.synopsis: Australia's richest person Gina Rinehart has increased her stake in lithium firm Liontown Resources as global lithium giant Albemarle seeks to take it over. Meanwhile, the ASX has fallen. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Gina Rinehart ups stake in lithium miner Liontown Resources, ASX in the red

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market remains in the red at lunchtime, but it's recovered some ground. The ASX 200 index has dropped 0.2 per cent to 7,180. Most sectors are in the red with energy stocks and banks weighing on the index. Petrol refiner and service station owner Viva Energy (-7 per cent) has slumped on a media report that major shareholder Vitol could trim its stake. Miners are doing the best thanks to higher copper and iron ore prices. Liontown Resources shares are down 0.3 per cent to $3.00 after Gina Rinehart's Hancock Prospecting raised its stake. Last week, Liontown accepted a $6.6 billion takeover bid from global lithium giant Albemarle. Best and worst performers: Telix Pharmaceuticals: +3.5% Megaport: +2.3% Ingenia Communities: +1.9% Viva Energy: -7.3% Syrah Resources: -5.7% Chalice Mining: -5.7%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian market comes off its lows

children.content: The Australian share market remains in the red at lunchtime, but it's recovered some ground.
The ASX 200 index has dropped 0.2 per cent to 7,180.
Most sectors are in the red with energy stocks and banks weighing on the index.
Petrol refiner and service station owner
Viva Energy
(-7 per cent) has slumped on a media report that major shareholder Vitol could trim its stake.
Miners are doing the best thanks to higher copper and iron ore prices.
Liontown Resources shares are down 0.3 per cent to $3.00 after Gina Rinehart's Hancock Prospecting raised its stake.
Last week, Liontown accepted a $6.6 billion takeover bid from global lithium giant
Albemarle.
Best and worst performers:
Telix Pharmaceuticals: +3.5%
Megaport: +2.3%
Ingenia Communities: +1.9%
Viva Energy: -7.3%
Syrah Resources: -5.7%
Chalice Mining: -5.7%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The National Australia Bank says business conditions held up last month despite the slowing economy. Business conditions rose 2 points in August with trading conditions, profitability and employment all increasing across most industries. Conditions were the best in manufacturing, but conditions fell sharply in the wholesale industry. Business confidence edged up by 2 index points, but it remains below average. And confidence is mixed across industries, with confidence remaining weakest in retail as people cut back on spending because of the high cost of living. Weighing on sentiment is a fall in forward orders, especially in car retailing and personal and household goods. NAB says that partly reflects normalising order books as backlogs are cleared. Confidence was also negative in mining, finance, business and property. National Australia Bank chief economist Alan Oster says businesses continue to face rising costs, including higher wages and purchasing costs. "Price growth also remains elevated which reflects the considerable cost pressures businesses are facing, as well as the ongoing resilience of demand." "We expect inflation to remain elevated in Q3 (quarter 3)." Mr Oster says demand for labour remained strong.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Business conditions and confidence edge higher

children.content: The
National Australia Bank
says business conditions held up last month despite the slowing economy.
Business conditions
rose 2 points in August with trading conditions, profitability and employment all increasing across most industries.
Conditions were the best in manufacturing, but conditions fell sharply in the wholesale industry.
Business confidence
edged up by 2 index points, but it remains below average.

props.alt: Red and black lines on graph showing business confidence and conditions

children.content: Business survey
(National Australia Bank )
And confidence is mixed across industries, with confidence remaining weakest in retail as people cut back on spending because of the high cost of living.
Weighing on sentiment is a fall in
forward orders
, especially in car retailing and personal and household goods.
NAB says that partly reflects normalising order books as backlogs are cleared.

props.alt: Graph showing forward orders in the retail industry

children.content: Retail orders
(National Australia Bank )
Confidence was also negative in mining, finance, business and property.
National Australia Bank chief economist Alan Oster says businesses continue to face rising costs, including higher wages and purchasing costs.
"Price growth also remains elevated which reflects the considerable cost pressures businesses are facing, as well as the ongoing resilience of demand."
"We expect inflation to remain elevated in Q3 (quarter 3)."
Mr Oster says demand for labour remained strong.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The union representing Chevron gas workers says it will oppose an attempt by the energy giant to have strike action at two major LNG projects ended by the industrial umpire. Negotiations between the Offshore Alliance union and Chevron over pay and conditions have broken down. Chevron has applied to the Fair Work Commission asking it to intervene in the strike, which began on Friday at the Gorgon and Wheatstone projects in northern Western Australia. Chevron wants the commission to halt the industrial action through an intractable bargaining declaration and says there is no reasonable prospect of an agreement on a new EBA. But the Offshore Alliance says it opposes the application. "The Offshore Allliance are opposing Chevron's IBD applications and want PIA (protected industrial action) to continue until we secure a union negotiated EBA." Work stoppages of up to 10 hours a day are expected to last until Thursday when a two-week strike is expected to kick off if there is no deal. There will be a directions hearing today on Chevron's application in the Fair Work Commission. Gas prices in Europe have surged, with the two projects responsible for more than 5 per cent of global LNG supply.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Gas unions to oppose Chevron attempts to halt LNG strike

children.content: The union representing Chevron gas workers says it will oppose an attempt by the energy giant to have strike action at two major LNG projects ended by the industrial umpire.
Negotiations between the Offshore Alliance union and Chevron over pay and conditions have broken down.
Chevron has applied to the Fair Work Commission asking it to intervene in the strike, which began on Friday at the Gorgon and Wheatstone projects in northern Western Australia.
Chevron wants the commission to halt the industrial action through an
intractable bargaining declaration
and says there is no reasonable prospect of an agreement on a new EBA.
But the Offshore Alliance says it opposes the application.
"The Offshore Allliance are opposing Chevron's IBD applications and want PIA (protected industrial action) to continue until we secure a union negotiated EBA."
Work stoppages of up to 10 hours a day are expected to last until Thursday when a two-week strike is expected to kick off if there is no deal.
There will be a directions hearing today on Chevron's application in the Fair Work Commission.
Gas prices in Europe have surged, with the two projects responsible for more than 5 per cent of global LNG supply.

image.altText: Angus Brayshaw is lying on a stretcher with a neck brace on and his eyes closed

items.synopsis: As Collingwood defender Brayden Maynard prepares to face the tribunal for his hit on Melbourne's Angus Brayshaw, the rest of the league awaits a verdict which some believe could shape the future of the game.

title.children: Only 35pc of adults are eating enough veg, with alcohol and takeaway dominating diets, report finds

image.altText: Tom Curry is shown a yellow card

items.synopsis: Four games. Five similar incidents. Three different decisions. As rugby grapples with its head-contact rules, players and coaches plead for consistency, writes Simon Smale.

title.children: 'We are frustrated by that': Rugby World Cup red-card lottery highlighted after week one

image.altText: New York jets quarterback Aaron Rodgers is tackled by Buffalo Bills defensive end Leonard Floyd in their NFL season opener.

items.synopsis: Aaron Rodgers leaves the Jets' season opener with an ankle injury in the fourth minute after he arrived from Green Bay on a two-year deal worth $117 million.

title.children: The New York Jets paid more than $100 million for quarterback Aaron Rodgers. He lasted four plays

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happened.

title.children: Portuguese street turns red as millions of litres of wine spill. Catch up with The Loop

title.children: 'Thank you darling': How simple phrases of love turned Jimmy's life upside down

items.synopsis: Police are investigating after a man in his 20s died while abseiling at Belmore Falls in Barrengarry.

title.children: Man dies after falling from a cliff while abseiling in Southern Highlands

image.altText: A boy faces a teacher who is standing in front of a blackboard.

items.synopsis: Students who study secondary school teaching at university will have the cost of their degrees covered by the Victorian government in a plan to boost the supply of teachers.

title.children: Victorian government to cover the cost of some teaching degrees to ease shortage

image.altText: A cowgirl wearing blue jeans and a pink shirt stands behind chutes a a rodeo

items.synopsis: Cowgirls from across the country have converged on outback Queensland for the nation's first female rodeo. Organisers say it's a huge leap toward creating pathways for passionate stockwomen in the male-dominated sport.

title.children: Usually cowgirls need to ride in the US to forge a career. An outback rodeo is changing that

image.altText: Woman smiling leaning on fence

items.synopsis: A renter says her life was saved by a concerned property agent after mould began to engulf the walls of her former home.

title.children: Mould in Prudence's rental home could have killed her, but help came from a surprising place

image.altText: A composite of two images of a man wearing a cap and a hoodie, captured by doorbell camera

items.synopsis: A convicted murderer who escaped from prison in the United States more than a week ago has eluded capture after slipping through a police search perimeter, changing his appearance, stealing a dairy delivery van and contacting acquaintances.

title.children: Murderer who 'crab-walked' out of US prison remains on run after stealing van, changing appearance

image.altText: An aerial view shows the charred remains of a building, with sparse trees nearby

items.synopsis: With a seemingly endless supply of guns, money and young men willing to act as mercenaries, tribal fighting in PNG has become akin to guerilla warfare.

title.children: Violence is so bad in this PNG community that police sealed it off to outsiders. The ABC got to go inside

items.synopsis: Meet the woman tracking ocean acidification in the Pacific — a rising danger that could destroy marine life and livelihoods.

image.altText: An historic homestead with a light tin roof and a veranda with sculptured plants growing in front.

items.synopsis: The historic 2,020-hectare property and homestead is said to provide the gold standard for environmental education in the country.

title.children: Sovereign Hill refuses to rule out selling historic property Narmbool, donated two decades ago
